speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in Case 11-94, Southern Union Company v. The United States. Mr. Phillips.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Was that jury trial constitutionally required?MR. PHILLIPS:  Yes, I believe the jury trial was constitutionally required, Justice Scalia.  The cutoff between what's a petty offense not subject to jury trial and what's beyond that -- I think you could -- you could get there two ways.  This is a crime that Congress attaches a 5-year penalty to if it's against an individual, which suggests that it is a very serious crime.  And the maximum fine under the district judge's interpretation of this would have been $38 million, even though the judge chose only to impose an $18 million penalty under these circumstances.  So, either way, it seems to me clearly a serious offense.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What have we said is the standard for fines?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What have we said with reference to a jury trial when fines are involved?  Does it have to be a substantial fine or do we have a word that we use?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, you have to do that because you have to know whether -- whether to impanel a jury before the -- before the jury comes in or before the jury comes in with a penalty, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Do we assume for purposes of this case that your client, a corporation, has a Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What are the peers of the Southern Union Company that would sit on the jury? Other railroads?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But it's not -- the jury didn't say that the defendant was in violation only 1day.  It said it was in violation within this span of many months, and it didn't say how many days.  It didn't say whether it was every day or 1 day or 10 days.  It just didn't focus on the number of days.  But it didn't find they were in violation only 1 day, which is what your opening statement was.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The most -- the most you must read out of it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes.  You could -- you could say it could have meant -- they could have thought that they violated every day.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You can't say that for sure.  But one thing you can say for sure is that they found that it violated it 1 day.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I didn't think --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I mean, I was -- I tend tobe in dissent in these cases; so, I don't have the authoritative view.  But the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, but no.  But the impression I have is that -- that I had thought there were what I'd call the elements of the offense, and then there were sentencing facts.  And sentencing facts have been traditionally facts found by the judge when imposing a sentence. Now, the majority of the Court in Apprendi went back into the history and said there is no significant old tradition, old enough, of -- of sentencing facts.  So, really, when you raise the sentence, that's like an element, and you should have a jury trial. Now, the argument here, one of them, that the government stresses -- and Ice is the same -- is that there is no -- the tradition's different where fines and where multiple and concurrent sentences were at issue. If you go back to the 18th century or earlier, what you'll discover is that the judge has always had a much greater role in deciding what theamount of a fine should be.  And, therefore, insofar as that amount rested upon some view of the facts as to the manner in which the crime occurred -- and it always does -- it was the judge who traditionally found it, not the jury.  So, those facts are not like elements of the crime. That's what I thought was essentially the argument.  Ice and fines are on one side of that line, and Apprendi is on the other.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no.  They're not doing that here.  What they're deciding is a fact of sentencing is how often this crime was committed.  No one can go against the statutory limit, but rather it -- it allows a higher sentence when certain facts occur. Now, I thought in Apprendi that the history is just what I'm saying it was in -- in the fine case,but the majority says to the contrary.  And so, here it seems, even if I was wrong in Apprendi, that at least there's enough discretion here to say, look, this is traditionally up to the judge.  Now, why do you think that isn't so?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Phillips, do you think that you could say that there was no going above the statutory maximum here?  In other words, you know, if the judge had said, well, it's $500 a day, I'm going to find some facts and fine you $600 a day, that would be going above a statutory maximum. But I'm wondering whether this is different because here the judge was sticking to the $500 a day that was set out in the statute, and then the question is more, you know, of an -- is it an element or is it a -- is it a sentencing fact as to how many days theviolation occurred?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Was there an objection at trial to the charge on the ground that it didn't instruct the jury to find the number of days of violation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You have no inducementto --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But this was in the context where the entire defense of the corporation was consistent with what the indictment said.  It was between the dates on or about, and there -- it would be very strange under this evidence to think that it was only there for 1 day, when it was spilled and they came back.  And so, that just doesn't make any sense.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I think there's -- that's just more a sense of background.  I do think we have to reach the issue you -- you present as if it were just -- as if there were no evidence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But I -- like Justice Ginsburg, I was very surprised the government didn't allege -- didn't stress waiver here.  You didn't submit an instruction?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Phillips, can you deal with one policy argument that your adversary raisedthat gives me some pause?  And that is, the number of days is certainly something that the jury here could -- relatively easily decided upon.  It could have looked at the evidence and figured that out --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- okay?  But in fraud cases, in securities cases, sometimes the identity of victims is not determined for months, till months after the conviction, and the amount of fine and/or restitution is set at sentencing. What's going to happen to all of those statutes --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- because -- or all of those procedures that have been set up by Congress to sort of set the amount of loss and repayment?  Are all of those subject to the Apprendi rule?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, isn't -- aren't fines indeterminate here by definition, going back toJustice Kagan's question?  There's no upper limit to how much the fine could be here.  It's set -- the upper limit is set by the number of days, but why is it different?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Why is restitution --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, so -- so --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So, how about when a fine is set by the value of the loss?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's no different than restitution.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: My goodness, I think there's lots of statutes that say something like this: That within limits, if there's a particular --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, leave that out because we assume -- right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It says, the fine, the maximum fine is going to be "not more than the greater of twice the gross gain or twice the gross loss."

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, you're going to send that to the jury.  Let me read you the next phase -- phrase:  "unless imposition of a fine under this subsection would unduly complicate or prolong the sentencing process." I point to that next phrase to show you that Congress understands, in an antitrust case, in a RICO case, in a corruption case of different kinds, in an environmental case, it is so complicated figuring out that kinds of things that they excuse even the judge who's experienced in this from dealing with that.  And under your theory, as you just point out, if Apprendi applies here, we're suddenly telling juries to -- they have to under the Constitution administer that section 18 U.S.C. 3571, which I just read to you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, I understand you could say that's what the Constitution provides, and if you jury can't handle it, well, too bad.  Okay.  But I think we're still in the business of trying to decide whether the Constitution does provide that in the case of fines.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is that a tail?  Is that a tail that the jury proceeding is itself so unadministrable that even Congress says we recognize even a judge couldn't do it?  All right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, is that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is that an irrelevant consideration when you are trying to figure out whether an ambiguous history requires the jury trial?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: There was no maximum.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Congress permitted --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And what's -- what --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- in 1790 indeterminate sentences as well, with no statutory maximum for jail.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So, they did both --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- with respect to fines and --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So, if the judge can -- if it's totally up to the discretion of the judge, that's fine; but if Congress enacts a statute that structures the fine -- and says, if this is the case, then so much; if that's the case, then so much more -- then you have to have a jury trial?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What sense does that make?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Isn't that precisely what Apprendi said?  Is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: That may be what Apprendi said, but is it consistent with the original meaning of the jury trial right in the Sixth Amendment?  These statutes give me pause on that score.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What do you make of thisold case that the Government cites, U.S. v. Tyler?  And it was the question of -- the penalty was four times the value of the goods, and this Court said the judge, not the jury, is responsible for imposing the fine and, therefore, also for determining the value of the goods.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: If you were to prevail, I -- I think it would be a rather simple matter for the parties to frame an instruction:  We find the defendant guilty and that the pollutant was retained for X days,much of what they do in a drug case.  That's one way to do it.  Could the government do it by the indictment? Could it indict alternatively, indict on count 1 for 10 days, count 2 for 50 days, or something like that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Maybe -- is that the way it often works or --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, that's why I am surprised the government waived it, and I thought that's what the evidence showed anyway.  But that's not before us.  That's not the way the case is presented here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: How, in general -- I mean, in the individual case, very often a trial doesn't come up because 90 percent or more of the time it's just a question of a plea bargain; and, therefore, the defendant doesn't -- this is an added weapon for him, Apprendi.  But in your -- with your clients and the others,there might be quite a lot of trials. So, how in a trial does your client or others in that position defend on the ground of we didn't do this at all; but by the way, in case you decide to the contrary, jury, we want to tell you we only did it Monday, Wednesday, and Friday? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: How is that supposed to work?  Do you have two juries?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Phillips. Mr. Dreeben.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You agree, don't you, that the statement in Oregon v. Ice was pure dicta?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Dreeben, I think the reference -- it was a fleeting reference to fines, and it could have meant that the judge has discretion to set the fine up to the maximum in the statute.  That's one possible meaning.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: This was -- you're not arguing that this rule will apply only to fines against corporations?  It would also apply to individuals, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's up to the judge todecide how many days or what the value was and so forth. Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So, the right to trial by jury to have that very important fact found does not exist, even for individuals?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm not sure how you can fully make that argument, because I thought the history was set forth fairly clearly in Apprendi that the early history was that nothing was given to the jury with respect to imprisonment or fines because most if not all sentences were indeterminate.  It's only when States began, and the Federal government, to experiment with determinate sentences that the Apprendi issue then became live.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So, explain to me, other than your reliance on Ice, some sort of tradition, which, you know, we can debate whether you can draw any conclusion from tradition in any of these areas, whether it's imprisonment or fines. Tell me on the logic of Apprendi, not using Ice, why fines are different, without relying on history, which to me is -- I view it as ambiguous. Okay?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I thought it was a fairly simple algorithm.  It says if the statutory penalty -- if a judge's factfinding can increase the statutory penalty, then that's a violation of the Sixth Amendment. A jury has to find any fact that increases the statutory maximum.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So, outside of a -- a -- imprisonment, there is no other penalty that Congress could fashion because it has no history that wouldn't be within the purview of the judge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But, Mr. Dreeben, wasn't the core domain defined by whether it related to a specific statutory offense?  So, Ice says the core concern is "a legislative attempt to remove from the province of the jury the determination of facts that warrant a punishment for a specific statutory offense."  How is that not relevant precisely in this context?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: How does it not determine this context?  I mean, those --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It's kind of odd, though, isn't it?  I mean, to some extent, this is a little easier case for you, because it does involve a corporation.  But there are statutes where the amount of imprisonment and the amount of a fine can both increase based on a particular fact.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And under your submission, if you have -- you know, say a defendant who is subject to 1 year, and that if a particular fact is found, he's subject to 2 years, a fine of 20 but then 40, the judge would be constitutionally prohibited from increasing the prison sentence but would be perfectly free to increase the fine --MR. DREEBEN:  Probably --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- including in a situation where the fine might be a lot more serious than the -- the time in prison.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Sure, he operated -- he operated in a reasonable way.  But we give juries the discretion to be unreasonable.  It would not -- juries often compromise.  So, if the instructions and the verdict told the jury you can find the defendant, you know, guilty for 1 day or whatever it is -- the 30million; 50,000 or 30 million -- it would not be at all unusual for the jury to debate and say, well, let's find him guilty for 10 million.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And return that verdict.  The judge is constrained by reason in a way that the jury is not, and that's sort of -- that's part of the protection the Sixth Amendment provided.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: A very -- very simple matter for the government to ask for jury findings on the questions at issue in this case, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Dreeben, let's talk about Tyler.  Tyler was not argued before this Court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's a one-page opinion. It's later described quite accurately as focusing not upon the amount of the fine, but rather upon amisdescription of pot ashes as pearl ashes, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Quite so.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The jury did find it in Tyler, though, didn't it?  The question was submitted to the jury, wasn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why doesn't -- why doesn't that indicate what the historical practice was?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Did it -- as a matter of statutory construction, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Might have helped if they had argument, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What about all of the 19th-century cases cited by Justice Thomas's concurrence in Apprendi?  Fine cases.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: In which course -- in which courts did indeed require the amount of the fines to be found by the jury.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Was it an argued case, at least?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What makes acceptable common law?  Let's assume there weren't 50 States back then, but whatever the number was, 20 States, and 15 of them submitted it to the jury and 5 didn't.  Does that mean there was no common law that this was generally submitted to the jury?  If you can point to one case, that's enough to defeat the existence of a common law view?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That -- you see, that's my problem.MR. DREEBEN:  And I don't disagree with you on that point, Justice Sotomayor; but I think that there is one fact that truly stands out about fines, and that is they were historically at common law products of judicial discretion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But so was imprisonment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, how many statutes had anything but indeterminate fine structures?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: How many statutes in the early common law had anything but indeterminate fine statutes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If it's varied and complicated, why should we -- assuming that it's ambiguous, why should we adopt the strange rule that the jury has to find the fact if you go to jail for 2 weeks, but doesn't have to find the fact if the amount of finesmultiplied by number of days or by anything else will -- will make a pauper of you?  Why would we adopt such a strange rule?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Unless compelled to do -- to do so by a clear common law history?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What about the other two? I just -- I was very interested in your colloquy here. You said, well, there were three cases in the 19th century where they did say the jury --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And one of them was a very brief opinion from Massachusetts.MR. DREEBEN:  Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, Massachusetts counts in its favor, but perhaps the brief opinion doesn't. The -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What about the other two?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Both Massachusetts.  Well, it's getting stronger.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What if the judge disagreed with the jury about whether there was even a violation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No, no, no, no.  The jury finds a violation, but the judge thinks the jury got it wrong.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: How does -- how does he pick the -- the number of days?  He flips a coin?MR. DREEBEN:  Unless the -- the judge finds that the evidence is insufficient under Jackson v. Virginia, he's bound by the jury.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No, he finds, you know, they could have come out that way, but -- but they were wrong.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's the whole problem. That is indeed the whole problem.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The judge can simply say, well, you know, all in all, probably they did it -- probably.  More likely than not they did it so many days.  It's a big difference.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: What other rules do you think are different?  I mean, is there a jury trial in the one case but not in the other?  Is there a right to counsel in the one case but not in the other?  What else turns on this fine/incarceration distinction?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What if you call it a misdemeanor but -- but impose a very heavy fine?  It's still a misdemeanor?MR. DREEBEN:  It is still a misdemeanor because the primary indication --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And you don't have right to counsel.  Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And that makes it clear to you that there's no overlap between property and liberty, so that no matter how much of your property are taken and what circumstances, it's just property; there's no liberty involved?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But you want -- want us to write as part of that decision that no matter how great the fine, liberty is not involved?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Liberty in the sense of what the Fifth Amendment and the Fourteenth amendment say.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, your --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes.  I guess you don't need counsel on any suits against corporations, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Your argument isn't limited to corporations, though.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So, do you need any more than that?  I mean, do we have to get into this?  Isn't it just a question of whether there is a tradition in the law that juries, rather than judges, would determine what used to be called sentencing facts; facts related not to the crime, but to the imposition of the punishment where that's a fine?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Sure.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Phillips, you have 7 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about the amount of loss issue that Justice Breyer raised, was very complicated to determine what the amount of the loss is?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: If we --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: If -- on the question of the value of goods or the amount of the loss, what would the standard be?  Would the jury have to find beyond a reasonable doubt that it was -- that the value was such and such?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I may have just forgotten, but does your brief go through the status of what lower courts have decided with respect to fines and how they're dealing with them?  I just don't remember it as being part of your brief, the statement you just made to Justice Kennedy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel, counsel. The case is submitted.
